title: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Child Functional Nausea and Vomiting
desc: The Rome IV Criteria for Child Functional Nausea and Vomiting provides criteria for diagnosis of child functional nausea and vomiting.

orgreference.text: Hyams J, Di lorenzo C, Forbes D, et al. Childhood functional gastrointestinal disorders: child/adolescent. Gastroenterology. 2006;130(5):1527-37.

data.evidence:
Functional nausea

To fulfill the Rome IV criteria for child functional nausea, patient must have the following (for ≥2 months prior):

  1. Bothersome nausea as the predominant symptom, occurring ≥2 times per week, and generally not related to meals.
  2. Not consistently associated with vomiting.
  3. After appropriate evaluation, the nausea cannot be fully explained by another medical condition.

Functional vomiting

To fulfill the Rome IV criteria for child functional vomiting, patient must have the following (for ≥2 months prior):

  1. On average, ≥1 episode of vomiting per week.
  2. Absence of self-induced vomiting or criteria for an eating disorder or rumination.
  3. After appropriate evaluation, the vomiting cannot be fully explained by another medical condition.

inputs.label_en: The occurrence of at least two episodes lasting hours to days during a six-month period of severe, unrelenting nausea and paroxysmal vomiting.
The main symptom, bothersome nausea, usually doesn't correspond with meals and happens ≥2 times per week.
